Yeah, sometimes people use it that way. But when you need to implement some generic thing that works on more than one type, you either end up with macros (_Generic is a bit better than nothing...) or void*, which are not as powerful as templates.

I really tried liking C. I wrote in in for 9 months on my job. I understand why it's good for low level stuff, but for high level it's a mess and not as productive compared to C++ (or hell, C#, Lua and Python)

A ton of CVEs that get discovered are about libs written in C. It's really easy to have memory corruption/buffer overflow etc. in C, even on simple things, like working with strings. When the string library is inherently save, you get safety and ease of use.

I understand why it's exciting to do a new language which solves every problem (most end up introducing new problems instead), but until it gets mainstream adoption, it'll be "just another language". And porting existing libraries/software to a new language is really expensive.

Yeah, that's my problem with C++ too. https://bitbashing.io/std-visit.html - this thing summarizes it well. But also you can't just remove the bad parts from C++ entirely, otherwise you'll get Python2 vs Python3 situation, but considerably worse.
Yeah, I think that C++ should either stop pretending it supports C or stay up to date to the latest C standard.

I like type safety in Go more than in C/C++ - you get strongly typed typedefs, so you can't go between typedef and it's underlying type implicitly. I wish C/C++ had that.
But yeah, I mostly avoid templates and "generic" stuff as much as possible. I've only encountered the need for them in serialization, data structures and math (e.g. int vs double vectors/rectangles)

templates are okay to debug with IDEs, but can be painful with gdb, yeah. At least they produce real functions, not some text substitutions, so you can actually set breakpoints inside template functions. And they get inlined very well

Most of the bugs I've seen that were on high level were related to complex logic which wouldn't be easier in C. Tons of CVEs discovered in "good" libraries and a lot of software (and other libs) depend on them. Two examples: http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvekey.cgi?keyword=openssh … http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvekey.cgi?keyword=libpng …

Yeah, C is okay for low-level stuff, where you start working on a bit/byte level and need things to work as fast as possible. But we see less and less need for that, there's more need to write safe systems and multi threaded ones, which are very hard to do in C.

What does Zig does that other languages didn't attempt to do? I've seen many "better C++" languages, but they don't really "replace" C++. The greatest candidate for replacing C++ is Rust, but it's still too niche and it'll take at least a decade for it to become mainstream.

For me, C++17 added three useful features: 1) std::filesystem - can finally work with FS without dependency on any other library 2) structured bindings: for (const auto& [key, value] : someMap) { ... } 3) std::optional is more expressive than raw pointers

C++ doesn't have that much OOP features, imo. It's mostly template/standard library features, which are added to the standard. OOP and legacy burden usually come from bad design patterns, which are encountered in any language.

And yeah, I can agree that C++14 was mostly a "bugfix" standard for C++11. C++17 brought tons of useful stuff like if constexpr, filesystem, structured bindings, optional, any, variant, etc. And C++20 will be huge and totally won't be "just a fix" standard.

Suppose I want to store tileset IDs as ints. I do: using TilesetID = int; And now I can do: std::unoredered_map tilesets. ... but if you do "struct TilesetID { int val; }", you won't be able to use it as a key for hash map without std::hash.
This approach is good, but sadly it doesn't work as well with std::map/std::unordered_map, as you now need to define operator> and std::hash specialization.

I've seen void* being used as a replacement for generics/template stuff, e.g. generic data structures. It's kinda painful. And I didn't intend to start a fight/argument, just sharing my thoughts, even though we have different viewpoints.

This is especially important when you work in a big team with tons of code. Yes, you yourself might write a perfectly safe code, but then someone modifies it and you get a CVE. People have different skills, and C has a really high skill requirements, while other languages don't.
There's already some "better C" languages out there: * Go - GC might be a problem, but not always * D with "-betterC" Both are still struggling to become mainstream, especially D.

The usefulness of features varies from case to case. A lot of the stuff that is added to C++ is useful for library authors, but then users get benefits from it too - e.g. Concepts will give us much better error messages, compile time evaluation makes libraries faster, etc.

Agreed, though C-style cast is worse. It's ok for short casts sometimes (e.g. (float)x instead of static_cast(x)), but C-style cast does all the casts, including const_cast under the hood, and not everyone knows that.

Nice article. Fully agreed, I hope that I don't see too much range-based code in the future on my work, because I've been stuck on clever use of stuff from too many times.

That's one of the downsides of C++. Instead of expanding the language, we add complex structures which feel like hacks sometimes. Looking at std::optional, std::any and std::variant which could have been a language feature.

Yeah. On the other hand, I appreciate Go's approach to this. Rob Pike doesn't like "clever" interfaces for things like "reduce", "filter", etc. - a lot of times simple for-loop is MUCH easier to read. Same as using std::find_if is not always easy to read.

However, there's a trade-off sometimes: you need to write complex lower level interfaces to make the remaining code easier. For example, I can write: const std::string str = jsonLoader["hello"].get_or("missing"); Easy to read and use, but JsonLoader is a very complex beast.
It supports most of it, the differences are very little in behaviour.
